<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">The introduction of various secondary N-donor ligands into an in situ ditetrazolate-ligand synthesis system of terephthalonitrile, NaN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and ZnCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> led to the formation of three new entangled frameworks Zn(pdtz)(4,4′-bipy)·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Zn(pdtz)(bpp)]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O <ce:bold>(2)</ce:bold> and Zn(pdtz)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>(N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)(2,2′-bipy) <ce:bold>(3)</ce:bold> (4,4′-bipy=4,4′-bipyridine; bpp=1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane; 2,2′-bipy=2,2′-bipyridine; H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pdtz=5,5′-1,4-phenylene-ditetrazole). The formation of pdtz<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand involves the Sharpless [2+3] cycloaddition reaction between terephthalonitrile and NaN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> in the presence of Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ion as a Lewis-acid catalyst under hydrothermal conditions. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits a fivefold interpenetrating 3D framework based on the diamondoid topology. Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> displays a twofold parallel interpenetrating framework based on the wavelike individual network. Compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> possesses a 2D puckered network. These new Zn–ditetrazolate frameworks are highly dependent on the modulation of different secondary N-donor ligands. Their luminescent properties were investigated.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

The introduction of various secondary N-donor ligands into an in situ ditetrazolate-ligand synthesis system of terephthalonitrile, NaN3 and ZnCl2 led to the formation of three new entangled frameworks Zn(pdtz)(4,4'-bipy)⋅3H2O (1), [Zn(pdtz)(bpp)]2⋅3H2O (2) and Zn(pdtz)0.5(N3)(2,2'-bipy) (3) (4,4'-bipy=4,4'-bipyridine; bpp=1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane; 2,2'-bipy=2,2'-bipyridine; H2pdtz=5,5'-1,4-phenylene-ditetrazole). The formation of pdtz2- ligand involves the Sharpless [2+3] cycloaddition reaction between terephthalonitrile and NaN3 in the presence of Zn2+ ion as a Lewis-acid catalyst under hydrothermal conditions. Compound 1 exhibits a fivefold interpenetrating 3D framework based on the diamondoid topology. Compound 2 displays a twofold parallel interpenetrating framework based on the wavelike individual network. Compound 3 possesses a 2D puckered network. These new Zn-ditetrazolate frameworks are highly dependent on the modulation of different secondary N-donor ligands. Their luminescent properties were investigated.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Three new entangled frameworks were prepared by an in situ ditetrazolate-ligand synthesis system assisted with various auxiliary N-donor ligands. The entangled structures can be modulated by different secondary ligands.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Three new entangled frameworks were prepared by an in situ ditetrazolate-ligand synthesis system assisted with various auxiliary N-donor ligands. The entangled structures can be modulated by different secondary ligands.

<ce:figure>
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The design and synthesis of entangled metal–organic frameworks have recently witnessed explosive growth in the areas of inorganic chemistry, coordination chemistry, crystal engineering and materials science, not only due to their intrinsic aesthetics value but also their potential applications in catalysis, gas storage, molecular adsorption, optical, electronic and magnetic materials . Although it is still difficult to prepare fully predictable entangled structures based on the rational design, recent rapid developments in coordination and organic chemistry provide more and more knowledge and possibilities for the creative synthesis of desired entangled frameworks . Especially in recent years, entangled frameworks have been well developed and systematically discussed in comprehensive reviews by Batten, Robson and Carlucci. In general, the entangled frameworks should possess at least two important structural factors: one is that their independent chain-, layer- or framework-units should contain meshes or pores which are large enough for interpenetration. The other, which is necessary, is that these individual building units should possess the undulating structural feature . Undoubtedly, various long chain-like N-donor ligands with diverse flexibility such as bipyridine- and biimidazole-containing ligands are good candidates for the assembly of versatile entangled structures, mainly because of their propensity to form large voids or corrugation . At this point, the bitetrazolate-containing ligands are also one kind of suitable building blocks since the tetra-N-donor property of the tetrazolate group can provide more coordination sites for metal centers to form complicated frameworks. Generally, the tetrazolate-containing ligands can be obtained from the classical Sharpless [2+3] cycloaddition reactions between cyano precursor and azide group, following by a series of complicated separation and purification steps . A recent advance in this synthesis suggests a shortcut, that is, the in situ synthesis of the tetrazolate-containing ligands from the cyano and azide precursors in a hydrothermal environment with various transition metal ions as the Lewis acid catalysts (as shown in Scheme S1) . Recently, Xiong et al. have reported a series of metal–monotetrazolate-based compounds isolated from such an in situ ligand synthesis system . Obviously, this method also suggests a possible route for the exploration of entangled metal–ditetrazolate systems. However, such reaction systems based on in situ synthesis of ditetrazolate ligands has been far unexplored . A possible reason is that these metal–ditetrazolate systems have few controllable factors to create, modulate or change the structural topologies during the assembly process. Nevertheless, the use of auxiliary ligands with various flexibility and coordination modes has proved to be an efficient way to dramatically influence the structural topologies . Therefore, utilizing secondary ligands in the above reaction systems may provide a promising strategy for the construction of new entangled metal–ditetrazolate frameworks.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and synthesis of entangled metal-organic frameworks have recently witnessed explosive growth in the areas of inorganic chemistry, coordination chemistry, crystal engineering and materials science, not only due to their intrinsic aesthetics value but also their potential applications in catalysis, gas storage, molecular adsorption, optical, electronic and magnetic materials . Although it is still difficult to prepare fully predictable entangled structures based on the rational design, recent rapid developments in coordination and organic chemistry provide more and more knowledge and possibilities for the creative synthesis of desired entangled frameworks . Especially in recent years, entangled frameworks have been well developed and systematically discussed in comprehensive reviews by Batten, Robson and Carlucci. In general, the entangled frameworks should possess at least two important structural factors: one is that their independent chain-, layer- or framework-units should contain meshes or pores which are large enough for interpenetration. The other, which is necessary, is that these individual building units should possess the undulating structural feature . Undoubtedly, various long chain-like N-donor ligands with diverse flexibility such as bipyridine- and biimidazole-containing ligands are good candidates for the assembly of versatile entangled structures, mainly because of their propensity to form large voids or corrugation . At this point, the bitetrazolate-containing ligands are also one kind of suitable building blocks since the tetra-N-donor property of the tetrazolate group can provide more coordination sites for metal centers to form complicated frameworks. Generally, the tetrazolate-containing ligands can be obtained from the classical Sharpless [2+3] cycloaddition reactions between cyano precursor and azide group, following by a series of complicated separation and purification steps . A recent advance in this synthesis suggests a shortcut, that is, the in situ synthesis of the tetrazolate-containing ligands from the cyano and azide precursors in a hydrothermal environment with various transition metal ions as the Lewis acid catalysts (as shown in Scheme S1) . Recently, Xiong et al. have reported a series of metal-monotetrazolate-based compounds isolated from such an in situ ligand synthesis system . Obviously, this method also suggests a possible route for the exploration of entangled metal-ditetrazolate systems. However, such reaction systems based on in situ synthesis of ditetrazolate ligands has been far unexplored . A possible reason is that these metal-ditetrazolate systems have few controllable factors to create, modulate or change the structural topologies during the assembly process. Nevertheless, the use of auxiliary ligands with various flexibility and coordination modes has proved to be an efficient way to dramatically influence the structural topologies . Therefore, utilizing secondary ligands in the above reaction systems may provide a promising strategy for the construction of new entangled metal-ditetrazolate frameworks.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Based on the aforementioned considerations, we deliberately chose an in situ synthesis system of 5,5′-1,4-phenylene-ditetrazole (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pdtz) ligands via mixing terephthalonitrile, NaN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and ZnCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (acting as Lewis acid catalyst), assisted with various secondary N-donor ligands such as 4,4′-bipyridine (4,4′-bipy), 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp) and 2,2′-bipyridine (2,2′-bipy). Our aim was to explore new entangled Zn–ditetrazolate frameworks and investigate the effect of various auxiliary ligands on the ultimate frameworks. Herein, we report three Zn–ditetrazolate-based compounds, Zn(pdtz)(4,4′-bipy)·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Zn(pdtz)(bpp)]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and Zn(pdtz)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>(N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)(2,2′-bipy) (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>). Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibit different interpenetrating frameworks, while compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> possesses undulated networks. Their structural topologies are highly dependent on the secondary N-donor ligands. The crystal structures, topological analyses and luminescent properties of <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold> have been well investigated.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Based on the aforementioned considerations, we deliberately chose an in situ synthesis system of 5,5'-1,4-phenylene-ditetrazole (H2pdtz) ligands via mixing terephthalonitrile, NaN3 and ZnCl2 (acting as Lewis acid catalyst), assisted with various secondary N-donor ligands such as 4,4'-bipyridine (4,4'-bipy), 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp) and 2,2'-bipyridine (2,2'-bipy). Our aim was to explore new entangled Zn-ditetrazolate frameworks and investigate the effect of various auxiliary ligands on the ultimate frameworks. Herein, we report three Zn-ditetrazolate-based compounds, Zn(pdtz)(4,4'-bipy)⋅3H2O (1), [Zn(pdtz)(bpp)]2⋅3H2O (2) and Zn(pdtz)0.5(N3)(2,2'-bipy) (3). Compounds 1 and 2 exhibit different interpenetrating frameworks, while compound 3 possesses undulated networks. Their structural topologies are highly dependent on the secondary N-donor ligands. The crystal structures, topological analyses and luminescent properties of 1-3 have been well investigated.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental section

Materials and methods

All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, N, and H) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer. FT/IR spectra were recorded in the range 4000-400cm-1 on an Alpha Centaut FT/IR spectrophotometer using KBr pellets. TG analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer TGA7 instrument in flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10°Cmin-1. Photoluminescence spectra were measured at room temperature using a FL-2T2 instrument (SPEX, USA) with a 450-W xenon lamp monochromatized by double gratings (1200gmu-1).

Caution! Azide salts are potentially explosive and should be handled in small quantities and with adequate precautions.

Synthesis of compounds 1-3 

Synthesis of Zn(pdtz)(4,4'-bipy)⋅3H2O (1)

Compound 1 was synthesized from a mixture of ZnCl2 (0.068g, 0.5mmol), NaN3 (0.039g, 0.6mmol), terephthalonitrile (TPN) (0.038g, 0.3mmol), 4,4'-bipy (0.047g, 0.3mmol), NaOH (0.01g, 0.25mmol) and H2O (10mL). This mixture was stirred for 20min at room temperature. Then the above mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave (20mL) and kept at 120°C for 3 days. After the reaction mixture had been slowly cooled at a rate of 10°Ch-1 to room temperature, block-like colorless crystals of 1 were obtained. The products were collected by filtration, washed with distilled water and dried in a desiccator at room temperature (yield: 58% based on Zn). Elemental analysis for C18H18N10O3Zn (Mr =487.81) (1): calcd: C 44.32, H 3.72, N 28.71%; found: C 44.28, H 3.69, N 28.72%. Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3348 (br), 1671 (m), 1612 (s), 1556 (m), 1535 (m), 1429 (s), 1272 (w), 1232 (m), 1170 (m), 1141 (m), 1071 (m), 1044 (m), 1009 (m), 865 (m), 817 (s), 751 (m), 727 (m), 647 (m), 545 (w), 491 (m), 460 (m).

All non-hydrogen atoms in the crystal data of <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold> were refined anisotropically except the solvent water molecules in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. H atoms on their parent C atoms were fixed in geometrically calculated positions, while H atoms on water molecules in the crystal structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were determined from the difference Fourier maps. Further details of the X-ray structural analysis are given in

elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Crystallographic data for compounds 1-3 were collected at 150K with a Rigaku R-axis Rapid IP diffractometer using graphite monochromatic MoKα radiation (λ=0.71073Å) and IP technique. The structures were solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on F 2 using the SHELXTL 97 crystallographic software package . All non-hydrogen atoms in the crystal data of 1-3 were refined anisotropically except the solvent water molecules in 2. H atoms on their parent C atoms were fixed in geometrically calculated positions, while H atoms on water molecules in the crystal structure of 1 were determined from the difference Fourier maps. Further details of the X-ray structural analysis are given in  . Selected bond lengths and angles of 1-3 are listed in Tables S1-S3, respectively.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Compounds <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold> were hydrothermally synthesized from the in situ ditetrazolate-ligand synthesis system assisted with various secondary N-donor ligands. The ditetrazolate ligand pdtz<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> was in situ synthesized through the Sharpless [2+3] cycloaddition reaction between terephthalonitrile and azide in the presence of Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ion as the Lewis acid catalyst under hydrothermal reaction conditions (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="sch1"></ce:float-anchor>) . This in situ ligand synthesis is proved to be convenient and environmentally friendly. In contrast, the traditional synthetic method of tetrazolates in acidic media usually release a large amount of heat as well as hydrazoic acid and thus the whole reaction system becomes highly toxic and explosive . During the present hydrothermal synthesis, various secondary N-donor ligands (4,4′-bipy, bpp and 2,2′-bipy) with different flexibility and coordination modes were introduced into the Zn–ditetrazolate system in order to modulate the structural topologies. As shown in , the use of rigid bridging-ligand 4,4′-bipy led to the isolation of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, which exhibits a fivefold interpenetrated 3D framework based on a diamondoid topology. In <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, both 4,4′-bipy and pdtz<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> are rigid linear ligands, resulting in an individual framework with very large pores for further interpenetration (see Fig. S1). When the flexible bpp ligand was employed as the auxiliary ligand, compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was isolated and displays a twofold parallel interpenetrating framework based on undulated layers. Although the Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibit a similar coordination mode to <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the bpp ligand endows itself an undulated TT (trans–trans) conformation (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="sch2"></ce:float-anchor>(b)) , looking like the letter “M”, which partly inhibits the formation of large channels and thus decreases the possibility of multiple interpenetration. The successful preparation of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> prompted us to try other auxiliary N-donor ligands. 2,2′-bipy, as one typical chelate ligand, usually plays important roles in “cutting” or “clipping” high-dimensional frameworks by occupying parts of the coordination sites on metal centers ((c)) and inducing low-dimensional wavelike networks or chains. The introduction of 2,2′-bipy into this Zn–ditetrazolate system led to the isolation of a puckered 2D networks of compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. Such 2D layers also possess narrow pores, whereas the adjacent layers cannot interpenetrate with each other because of the relative small meshes in the layers and the large steric hindrance from 2,2′-bipy ligands. It is worth mentioning that a little more azide ligand was used by accident during the synthesis of compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, which has been subsequently proved a very important step to isolate the final compound because the azide ligand also acted as linkers to connect the Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions in compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. Furthermore, 2,2′-bipy plays a ‘passivating’ role in providing steric constrains which can prevent large pdtz<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands from coordinating to the metal centers. If the same amount of azide was used as in the preparation of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> could not be isolated.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis

Compounds 1-3 were hydrothermally synthesized from the in situ ditetrazolate-ligand synthesis system assisted with various secondary N-donor ligands. The ditetrazolate ligand pdtz2- was in situ synthesized through the Sharpless [2+3] cycloaddition reaction between terephthalonitrile and azide in the presence of Zn2+ ion as the Lewis acid catalyst under hydrothermal reaction conditions (see  ) . This in situ ligand synthesis is proved to be convenient and environmentally friendly. In contrast, the traditional synthetic method of tetrazolates in acidic media usually release a large amount of heat as well as hydrazoic acid and thus the whole reaction system becomes highly toxic and explosive . During the present hydrothermal synthesis, various secondary N-donor ligands (4,4'-bipy, bpp and 2,2'-bipy) with different flexibility and coordination modes were introduced into the Zn-ditetrazolate system in order to modulate the structural topologies. As shown in , the use of rigid bridging-ligand 4,4'-bipy led to the isolation of compound 1, which exhibits a fivefold interpenetrated 3D framework based on a diamondoid topology. In 1, both 4,4'-bipy and pdtz2- are rigid linear ligands, resulting in an individual framework with very large pores for further interpenetration (see Fig. S1). When the flexible bpp ligand was employed as the auxiliary ligand, compound 2 was isolated and displays a twofold parallel interpenetrating framework based on undulated layers. Although the Zn2+ ions in 2 exhibit a similar coordination mode to 1, the bpp ligand endows itself an undulated TT (trans-trans) conformation (see  (b)) , looking like the letter "M", which partly inhibits the formation of large channels and thus decreases the possibility of multiple interpenetration. The successful preparation of 1 and 2 prompted us to try other auxiliary N-donor ligands. 2,2'-bipy, as one typical chelate ligand, usually plays important roles in "cutting" or "clipping" high-dimensional frameworks by occupying parts of the coordination sites on metal centers ((c)) and inducing low-dimensional wavelike networks or chains. The introduction of 2,2'-bipy into this Zn-ditetrazolate system led to the isolation of a puckered 2D networks of compound 3. Such 2D layers also possess narrow pores, whereas the adjacent layers cannot interpenetrate with each other because of the relative small meshes in the layers and the large steric hindrance from 2,2'-bipy ligands. It is worth mentioning that a little more azide ligand was used by accident during the synthesis of compound 3, which has been subsequently proved a very important step to isolate the final compound because the azide ligand also acted as linkers to connect the Zn2+ ions in compound 3. Furthermore, 2,2'-bipy plays a ‘passivating' role in providing steric constrains which can prevent large pdtz2- ligands from coordinating to the metal centers. If the same amount of azide was used as in the preparation of compound 1, compound 3 could not be isolated.

Compounds <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold> can only be prepared in a limited pH range (7.8–8.2), whereas no products can be obtained out of this pH range. If the pH value is lower than 7.8, the <mml:math altimg="si1.gif" overflow="scroll">

In these syntheses, the pH value of the reaction system may be adjusted by the NaOH solution. On the other hand, it has been found that the above reactions can be carried out in the temperature range of 120±10<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>°C. Compounds 1-3 can only be prepared in a limited pH range (7.8-8.2), whereas no products can be obtained out of this pH range. If the pH value is lower than 7.8, the      N    3   -     groups may be hydrolyzed and release hydrazoic acid. At pH values higher than 8.2, the cyano groups are inclined to hydrolysis and form the carboxylate groups. In these syntheses, the pH value of the reaction system may be adjusted by the NaOH solution. On the other hand, it has been found that the above reactions can be carried out in the temperature range of 120±10°C. If the reaction temperature is much lower or higher than 120°C, no crystals can be obtained. It is also notable that changing the ratio or concentration of reagents does not result in the final compounds 1-3.

</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Structure of Zn(pdtz)(4,4′-bipy)·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the monoclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>/c</ce:italic> and exhibits an interesting fivefold interpenetrated 3D framework based on a diamondoid topology. In the asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, there is one Zn center, one pdtz<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand, one 4,4′-bipy ligand and three solvent water molecules. As shown in Fig. S2, the Zn center exhibits a tetra-coordinated environment with two nitrogen atoms deriving from two different pdtz<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands and two nitrogen atoms originating from two different 4,4′-bipy ligands. The bond lengths of Zn–N are in the range of 1.9713(19)–2.0253(19)<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å and the bond angels of N–Zn–N vary from 108.66(8)° to 111.70(8)°. All pdtz<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands possess the same diagonal bidentate coordination mode (<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>-2,2′), that is, two N-donors from two tetrazolate groups coordinate with two different Zn atoms in a side-trans bridging fashion (see (e)). As a result, 10 Zn centers are connected by twelve bridging ligands, namely, six pdtz<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> and six 4,4′-bipy, generating a diamondoid cage (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>, left). Based on the secondary building unit (SBU) concept , tetrahedral {ZnN<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>} can be viewed as a tetrahedral SBU (Fig. S3, left), and the independent 3D diamondoid framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is composed of the tetrahedral SBUs connected by the linear linkers of pdtz<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> and 4,4-bipy ( and S1). The topological analysis of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> reveals that such a typical diamondoid framework contains large diamondoid cages with the topology symbol (6<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>)  and exhibits cyclohexane-like windows in a chair conformation ( and S1) . The distances between adjacent Zn⋯Zn centers linked by pdtz<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> and 4,4′-bipy bridges are 13.4055 and 11.1463<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. The void space in an individual framework is so large that five identical 3D diamondoid frameworks can interpenetrate with each other to form a fascinating five-fold interpenetrating fashion along <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>). Such an interpenetration mode can minimize the big void cavities of the diamondoid cages. It is worth mentioning that such an interpenetration mode is the first example in the metal–trazolate system. Furthermore, the adjacent entangled diamondoid frameworks possess weak π–π interactions  between aromatic rings of neighboring pdtz<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> and 4,4′-bipy ligands. The centroid–centroid distances of the aromatic rings between parallel pdtz–pdtz and bipy–bipy are 3.942 and 4.091<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. The isolated water molecules reside in the interspaces of the neutral channels.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of compounds 1-3 

Structure of Zn(pdtz)(4,4'-bipy)⋅3H2O (1)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21 /c and exhibits an interesting fivefold interpenetrated 3D framework based on a diamondoid topology. In the asymmetric unit of 1, there is one Zn center, one pdtz2- ligand, one 4,4'-bipy ligand and three solvent water molecules. As shown in Fig. S2, the Zn center exhibits a tetra-coordinated environment with two nitrogen atoms deriving from two different pdtz2- ligands and two nitrogen atoms originating from two different 4,4'-bipy ligands. The bond lengths of Zn-N are in the range of 1.9713(19)-2.0253(19)Å and the bond angels of N-Zn-N vary from 108.66(8)° to 111.70(8)°. All pdtz2- ligands possess the same diagonal bidentate coordination mode (μ-2,2'), that is, two N-donors from two tetrazolate groups coordinate with two different Zn atoms in a side-trans bridging fashion (see (e)). As a result, 10 Zn centers are connected by twelve bridging ligands, namely, six pdtz2- and six 4,4'-bipy, generating a diamondoid cage ( , left). Based on the secondary building unit (SBU) concept , tetrahedral {ZnN4} can be viewed as a tetrahedral SBU (Fig. S3, left), and the independent 3D diamondoid framework of 1 is composed of the tetrahedral SBUs connected by the linear linkers of pdtz2- and 4,4-bipy ( and S1). The topological analysis of 1 reveals that such a typical diamondoid framework contains large diamondoid cages with the topology symbol (66)  and exhibits cyclohexane-like windows in a chair conformation ( and S1) . The distances between adjacent Zn⋯Zn centers linked by pdtz2- and 4,4'-bipy bridges are 13.4055 and 11.1463Å, respectively. The void space in an individual framework is so large that five identical 3D diamondoid frameworks can interpenetrate with each other to form a fascinating five-fold interpenetrating fashion along b axis (see  ). Such an interpenetration mode can minimize the big void cavities of the diamondoid cages. It is worth mentioning that such an interpenetration mode is the first example in the metal-trazolate system. Furthermore, the adjacent entangled diamondoid frameworks possess weak π-π interactions  between aromatic rings of neighboring pdtz2- and 4,4'-bipy ligands. The centroid-centroid distances of the aromatic rings between parallel pdtz-pdtz and bipy-bipy are 3.942 and 4.091Å, respectively. The isolated water molecules reside in the interspaces of the neutral channels.

<ce:section-title>Structure of [Zn(pdtz)(bpp)]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> also crystallizes in the monoclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>/c</ce:italic> but displays a twofold parallel interpenetration framework based on undulated layers. In the asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, there is one crystallographically unique Zn center, one pdtz<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand, one bpp ligand and three solvent water molecules (as shown in Fig. S4). All the Zn centers exhibit the {ZnN<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>} tetrahedral coordination geometry with two N atoms derived from two different pdtz<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands and the other two N atoms from different bpp ligands. The bond lengths of Zn–N are in the range of 1.963(6)–2.022(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å and the bond angels of N–Zn–N vary from 102.8(2)° to 115.2(2)°. Both bpp ligands possess the undulated TT conformation , looking like the letter “M”. The distance between two N-donors is 9.6<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å (see (b)). All pdtz<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands adopt the same coordination modes as those in compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Based on above coordination modes, all the Zn centers are linked by the pdtz<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> and bpp ligands into a 2D wavelike network with square meshes (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>) and the topology symbol of the layer should be (4·4) . The square size is ca. 12.9<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å×13.2<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å (see Fig. S5). Such an undulated sheet with large square pores offers an ideal condition for the interpenetration. Actually, two identical sets of 2D parallel layers in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are interlocked with each other to form a two-fold parallel interpenetration framework (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>). Furthermore, all solvent water molecules in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> reside in the interspaces of the polycatenation framework. However, no visible channels can be found from the 3D packing arrangements (see Fig. S6), indicating that the crystal structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> contains relatively small and close interspaces. In addition, the π–π interactions between the aromatic rings of pdtz<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> and bpp ligands may further stabilize the whole 3D framework.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structure of [Zn(pdtz)(bpp)]2⋅3H2O (2)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that compound 2 also crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21 /c but displays a twofold parallel interpenetration framework based on undulated layers. In the asymmetric unit of 2, there is one crystallographically unique Zn center, one pdtz2- ligand, one bpp ligand and three solvent water molecules (as shown in Fig. S4). All the Zn centers exhibit the {ZnN4} tetrahedral coordination geometry with two N atoms derived from two different pdtz2- ligands and the other two N atoms from different bpp ligands. The bond lengths of Zn-N are in the range of 1.963(6)-2.022(5)Å and the bond angels of N-Zn-N vary from 102.8(2)° to 115.2(2)°. Both bpp ligands possess the undulated TT conformation , looking like the letter "M". The distance between two N-donors is 9.6Å (see (b)). All pdtz2- ligands adopt the same coordination modes as those in compound 1. Based on above coordination modes, all the Zn centers are linked by the pdtz2- and bpp ligands into a 2D wavelike network with square meshes (see  ) and the topology symbol of the layer should be (4⋅4) . The square size is ca. 12.9Å×13.2Å (see Fig. S5). Such an undulated sheet with large square pores offers an ideal condition for the interpenetration. Actually, two identical sets of 2D parallel layers in 2 are interlocked with each other to form a two-fold parallel interpenetration framework (see  ). Furthermore, all solvent water molecules in 2 reside in the interspaces of the polycatenation framework. However, no visible channels can be found from the 3D packing arrangements (see Fig. S6), indicating that the crystal structure of 2 contains relatively small and close interspaces. In addition, the π-π interactions between the aromatic rings of pdtz2- and bpp ligands may further stabilize the whole 3D framework.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Structure of Zn(pdtz)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>(N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)(2,2′-bipy) (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">When linear ligands 4,4′-bipy or bpp are replaced by the chelate ligand 2,2′-bipy, compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is obtained. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> crystallizes in the monoclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>/c</ce:italic> and exhibits a 2D puckered network. In the asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, there is one Zn center, half the pdtz<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand, one azido ligand, and one 2,2′-bipy ligand (as shown in Fig. S7). Different from the tetrahedral coordination geometry of {ZnN<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>} in compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the Zn centers in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> possess a distorted {ZnN<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>} octahedral coordination geometry with two N atoms deriving from two different pdtz<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands, two from one chelate 2,2′-bipy ligand, and the last two from two azido groups. The pdtz<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands also exhibit different coordination fashions in contrast to those in compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. In this case, the pdtz<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands act as a quadridentate ligand (namely <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>-2,3:2′,3′) coordinating with four Zn centers (see (f)). The 2,2′-bipy serves as a chelate ligand occupying two coordination sites of the Zn centers. Interestingly, the azide ligands also enter into the framework and act as linkers in an end-on (EO) mode to connect two adjacent Zn centers (see (d)). The bond distances between Zn and N-donor of azide ligands are in the range of 2.128(3)–2.491(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å, while the Zn–N<ce:inf loc="post">(azide)</ce:inf>–Zn angle is 114.91(11)°. All the other bond lengths of Zn–N in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are in the range of 2.086(2)–2.180(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å, and the bond angels of N–Zn–N vary from 75.98(7)° to 168.29(9)°. It is noteworthy that compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> represents the first metal–tetrazolate compound assisted with two types of auxiliary ligands at the same time. Based on above coordination modes, all the Zn centers are bridged by azide and tetrazolate group of pdtz<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands into a 1D chain running along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>-direction (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>). These 1D chains are further connected by the pdtz<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands into a 2D puckered layer (, 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig6"></ce:float-anchor>(a)). In such a network, the intra-chain Zn⋯Zn distance is 3.899(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å and inter-chain ones are 13.022(6) and 10.608(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively (see (a)). Furthermore, these 1D chains are decorated by 2,2′-bipy ligands on both sides of the undulated layer (see (a)). Because of such obvious steric hindrance of the 2,2′-bipy ligands on the layers, no interpenetration can be realized between the adjacent puckered networks. From the topological point of view (as shown in Scheme S2), the pdtz<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand can be abstracted as a flat ribbon, while the building unit {Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>} can be rationalized as a solid rod . Since 2,2′-bipy ligands only act as a decorating ligand, it is not necessary to consider it in the topological analysis. Based on this simplification, the networks of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> can be abstracted into a 2D undulated layer ((b), S8).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structure of Zn(pdtz)0.5(N3)(2,2'-bipy) (3)

When linear ligands 4,4'-bipy or bpp are replaced by the chelate ligand 2,2'-bipy, compound 3 is obtained. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that compound 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21 /c and exhibits a 2D puckered network. In the asymmetric unit of 3, there is one Zn center, half the pdtz2- ligand, one azido ligand, and one 2,2'-bipy ligand (as shown in Fig. S7). Different from the tetrahedral coordination geometry of {ZnN4} in compounds 1 and 2, the Zn centers in 3 possess a distorted {ZnN6} octahedral coordination geometry with two N atoms deriving from two different pdtz2- ligands, two from one chelate 2,2'-bipy ligand, and the last two from two azido groups. The pdtz2- ligands also exhibit different coordination fashions in contrast to those in compounds 1 and 2. In this case, the pdtz2- ligands act as a quadridentate ligand (namely μ-2,3:2',3') coordinating with four Zn centers (see (f)). The 2,2'-bipy serves as a chelate ligand occupying two coordination sites of the Zn centers. Interestingly, the azide ligands also enter into the framework and act as linkers in an end-on (EO) mode to connect two adjacent Zn centers (see (d)). The bond distances between Zn and N-donor of azide ligands are in the range of 2.128(3)-2.491(3)Å, while the Zn-N(azide)-Zn angle is 114.91(11)°. All the other bond lengths of Zn-N in 3 are in the range of 2.086(2)-2.180(2)Å, and the bond angels of N-Zn-N vary from 75.98(7)° to 168.29(9)°. It is noteworthy that compound 3 represents the first metal-tetrazolate compound assisted with two types of auxiliary ligands at the same time. Based on above coordination modes, all the Zn centers are bridged by azide and tetrazolate group of pdtz2- ligands into a 1D chain running along the c-direction ( ). These 1D chains are further connected by the pdtz2- ligands into a 2D puckered layer (,  (a)). In such a network, the intra-chain Zn⋯Zn distance is 3.899(1)Å and inter-chain ones are 13.022(6) and 10.608(2)Å, respectively (see (a)). Furthermore, these 1D chains are decorated by 2,2'-bipy ligands on both sides of the undulated layer (see (a)). Because of such obvious steric hindrance of the 2,2'-bipy ligands on the layers, no interpenetration can be realized between the adjacent puckered networks. From the topological point of view (as shown in Scheme S2), the pdtz2- ligand can be abstracted as a flat ribbon, while the building unit {Zn2N3} can be rationalized as a solid rod . Since 2,2'-bipy ligands only act as a decorating ligand, it is not necessary to consider it in the topological analysis. Based on this simplification, the networks of 3 can be abstracted into a 2D undulated layer ((b), S8).

elements.clean_text:
IR spectrum

In the IR spectra of compounds 1, 2 and 3 (Fig. S9), the diagnostic peak of the cyano group at 2100cm-1 disappeared, however, the emergence of the characteristic peaks (at 1612, 1556, 1535 and 1429cm-1 for 1, at ca. 1622, 1558, 1510 and 1437cm-1 for 2, and at ca. 1597, 1565, 1475 and 1433cm-1 for 3) suggests the formation of tetrazole groups, in good agreement with those of tetrazolate-based compounds previously reported . The existence of the bridging azide groups in the final framework of 3 is confirmed by the appearance of a strong band at 2049cm-1 in the IR spectrum, which is attributed to the typical asymmetric stretching of      N    3   -    . Furthermore, the v s(N3) stretching bands located at 1319 and 1288cm-1 indicate that the      N    3   -     should be in an EO bridging mode . In addition, the fingerprint peaks of 4,4'-bipy, bpp and 2,2'-bipy are overlapped with those of bptz2- in lower wavenumber regions and can not be exactly assigned. Peaks at 3348 and 3423cm-1 in the IR of compounds 1 and 2 are attributed to the vibration of water molecules, respectively. All the peak assignments are in agreement with the results of the single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies.

elements.clean_text:
Thermal analysis

The TG curves of compounds 1 and 2 (see Fig. S10(a) and (b)) both exhibit two weight-loss steps. The first minor weight-loss of 11.48% of 1 ranging from 106 to 162°C (5.42% of 2 between 108 and 136°C) corresponds to the release of the lattice water molecules. The second weight-loss of 75.06% of 1 in the temperature range of 196-450°C (81.62% of 2 between 182 and 380°C) can be ascribed to the loss of all organic ligands. The whole weight losses of 86.54% (for 1) and 87.05% (for 2) are in good agreement with the calculated values 86.59% (1) and 86.99% (2), respectively. The TG curve of compound 3 exhibits a different weight-loss feature (as shown in Fig. S10(c)). Only one continuous weight-loss step was found in the temperature range of 228-376°C with the whole weight loss of 82.14%, attributed to the successive release of pdtz2-,      N    3   -     and 2,2'-bipy ligands. This result is also well consistent with the calculated value 82.31%.

<ce:section-title>Fluorescent properties</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The luminescent properties of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. Since complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are stable in air and insoluble in water or most organic solvents, no additional measurements in solution were performed. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig7"></ce:float-anchor>, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> all exhibit strong fluorescent emission with the maxima at 468, 489 and 486<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>nm upon excitation at 358, 410 and 416<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>nm, respectively. This observation suggests that all three compounds may be excellent candidates for potential blue-emitted photoactive materials. In order to understand the nature of these emission bands, we compared the emission spectra of the three compounds and those of free organic ligands. The free H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pdtz ligand usually displays a broad emission peak with the emission maximum located at 473<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>nm , while the free 4,4′-bipy ligand does not emit any luminescence in the range of 400–800<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>nm . As shown in , compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits a similar emission peak at 468<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>nm to the free H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pdtz ligand. Hence, the emission of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be tentatively attributed to the intraligand transition of the Zn-modified pdtz<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands. In addition, the free bpp ligand usually emits intense luminescence at ca. 523<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>nm , obviously different from the emission peak of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (489<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>nm). Further, the free 2,2′-bipy ligand generally displays a weak luminescence at ca. 530<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>nm , also far from the emission peak of compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (486<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>nm). The blue shifts of emission bands occurring in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are probably due to the cooperative effects of intraligand emission and ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescent properties

The luminescent properties of compounds 1, 2 and 3 were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. Since complexes 1, 2, and 3 are stable in air and insoluble in water or most organic solvents, no additional measurements in solution were performed. As shown in  , 1, 2 and 3 all exhibit strong fluorescent emission with the maxima at 468, 489 and 486nm upon excitation at 358, 410 and 416nm, respectively. This observation suggests that all three compounds may be excellent candidates for potential blue-emitted photoactive materials. In order to understand the nature of these emission bands, we compared the emission spectra of the three compounds and those of free organic ligands. The free H2pdtz ligand usually displays a broad emission peak with the emission maximum located at 473nm , while the free 4,4'-bipy ligand does not emit any luminescence in the range of 400-800nm . As shown in , compound 1 exhibits a similar emission peak at 468nm to the free H2pdtz ligand. Hence, the emission of 1 can be tentatively attributed to the intraligand transition of the Zn-modified pdtz2- ligands. In addition, the free bpp ligand usually emits intense luminescence at ca. 523nm , obviously different from the emission peak of compound 2 (489nm). Further, the free 2,2'-bipy ligand generally displays a weak luminescence at ca. 530nm , also far from the emission peak of compound 3 (486nm). The blue shifts of emission bands occurring in 2 and 3 are probably due to the cooperative effects of intraligand emission and ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>X-ray powder diffraction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In order to check the phase purity of these compounds, the X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were checked at room temperature. As shown in Figs. S11–S13, the peak positions of simulated and experimental XRPD patterns are in agreement with each other, indicating the good phase purity of these compounds. The differences in intensity may be due to the preferred orientation of the crystalline powder samples.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray powder diffraction

In order to check the phase purity of these compounds, the X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) of 1, 2 and 3 were checked at room temperature. As shown in Figs. S11-S13, the peak positions of simulated and experimental XRPD patterns are in agreement with each other, indicating the good phase purity of these compounds. The differences in intensity may be due to the preferred orientation of the crystalline powder samples.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In summary, three new entangled Zn–ditetrazolate frameworks of <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold> were hydrothermally synthesized by an in situ ditetrazolate-ligand synthesis system assisted with various auxiliary N-donor ligands. These results demonstrate that the entangled Zn–ditetrazolate topological system can be modulated by choosing different secondary ligands. This work provides new paradigm for further rational design and synthesis of new entangled metal–organic frameworks via controlling auxiliary ligands. The blue emission of these compounds suggests that they may be potential candidates for blue-light emitting materials.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, three new entangled Zn-ditetrazolate frameworks of 1-3 were hydrothermally synthesized by an in situ ditetrazolate-ligand synthesis system assisted with various auxiliary N-donor ligands. These results demonstrate that the entangled Zn-ditetrazolate topological system can be modulated by choosing different secondary ligands. This work provides new paradigm for further rational design and synthesis of new entangled metal-organic frameworks via controlling auxiliary ligands. The blue emission of these compounds suggests that they may be potential candidates for blue-light emitting materials.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Caution! Azide salts are potentially explosive and should be handled in small quantities and with adequate precautions.

Synthesis of compounds 1-3 

Synthesis of Zn(pdtz)(4,4'-bipy)⋅3H2O (1)

Compound 1 was synthesized from a mixture of ZnCl2 (0.068g, 0.5mmol), NaN3 (0.039g, 0.6mmol), terephthalonitrile (TPN) (0.038g, 0.3mmol), 4,4'-bipy (0.047g, 0.3mmol), NaOH (0.01g, 0.25mmol) and H2O (10mL). This mixture was stirred for 20min at room temperature. Then the above mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave (20mL) and kept at 120°C for 3 days. After the reaction mixture had been slowly cooled at a rate of 10°Ch-1 to room temperature, block-like colorless crystals of 1 were obtained. The products were collected by filtration, washed with distilled water and dried in a desiccator at room temperature (yield: 58% based on Zn). Elemental analysis for C18H18N10O3Zn (Mr =487.81) (1): calcd: C 44.32, H 3.72, N 28.71%; found: C 44.28, H 3.69, N 28.72%. Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3348 (br), 1671 (m), 1612 (s), 1556 (m), 1535 (m), 1429 (s), 1272 (w), 1232 (m), 1170 (m), 1141 (m), 1071 (m), 1044 (m), 1009 (m), 865 (m), 817 (s), 751 (m), 727 (m), 647 (m), 545 (w), 491 (m), 460 (m).

Synthesis of [Zn(pdtz)(bpp)]2⋅3H2O (2)

Compound 2 was prepared with a similar procedure to 1 except that 4,4'-bipy was substituted by bpp (0.059g, 0.3mmol). Block-like colorless crystals of 2 were obtained (yield: 62% based on the Zn). Elemental analysis for C42H42N20O3Zn2 (Mr =1005.70) (2): calcd: C 50.16, H 4.21, N 27.85%; found: C 50.13, H 4.18, N 27.88%. Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3423 (br), 2075 (m), 1622 (s), 1558 (m), 1510 (w), 1437 (s), 1342 (w), 1229 (m), 1163 (m), 1141 (w), 1068 (m), 1038 (m), 1006 (m), 862 (m), 805 (m), 752 (m), 623 (w), 527 (w), 489 (m).

Synthesis of Zn(pdtz)0.5(N3)(2,2'-bipy) (3)

Compound 3 was synthesized in an analogous manner to 1 except that 4,4'-bipy was replaced by 2,2'-bipy (0.047g, 0.3mmol) and a little more NaN3 (0.046g, 0.7mmol) was used during the preparation. Block-like colorless crystals of 3 were isolated (yield: 48% based on the Zn). Elemental analysis for C14H10N9Zn (Mr =369.68) (3): calcd: C 45.49, H 2.73, N 34.10%; found: C 45.45, H 2.68, N 34.13%. Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm-1): 2049 (s), 1597 (m), 1565 (m), 1492 (m), 1433 (s), 1336 (m), 1319 (m), 1288 (m), 1252 (w), 1181 (m), 1155 (w), 1055 (w), 1020 (m), 902 (w), 890 (m), 770 (s), 734 (m), 651 (m), 629 (w), 540 (w), 493 (m), 420 (m).

cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermal analysis

The TG curves of compounds 1 and 2 (see Fig. S10(a) and (b)) both exhibit two weight-loss steps. The first minor weight-loss of 11.48% of 1 ranging from 106 to 162°C (5.42% of 2 between 108 and 136°C) corresponds to the release of the lattice water molecules. The second weight-loss of 75.06% of 1 in the temperature range of 196-450°C (81.62% of 2 between 182 and 380°C) can be ascribed to the loss of all organic ligands. The whole weight losses of 86.54% (for 1) and 87.05% (for 2) are in good agreement with the calculated values 86.59% (1) and 86.99% (2), respectively. The TG curve of compound 3 exhibits a different weight-loss feature (as shown in Fig. S10(c)). Only one continuous weight-loss step was found in the temperature range of 228-376°C with the whole weight loss of 82.14%, attributed to the successive release of pdtz2-,      N    3   -     and 2,2'-bipy ligands. This result is also well consistent with the calculated value 82.31%.

Fluorescent properties

The luminescent properties of compounds 1, 2 and 3 were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. Since complexes 1, 2, and 3 are stable in air and insoluble in water or most organic solvents, no additional measurements in solution were performed. As shown in  , 1, 2 and 3 all exhibit strong fluorescent emission with the maxima at 468, 489 and 486nm upon excitation at 358, 410 and 416nm, respectively. This observation suggests that all three compounds may be excellent candidates for potential blue-emitted photoactive materials. In order to understand the nature of these emission bands, we compared the emission spectra of the three compounds and those of free organic ligands. The free H2pdtz ligand usually displays a broad emission peak with the emission maximum located at 473nm , while the free 4,4'-bipy ligand does not emit any luminescence in the range of 400-800nm . As shown in , compound 1 exhibits a similar emission peak at 468nm to the free H2pdtz ligand. Hence, the emission of 1 can be tentatively attributed to the intraligand transition of the Zn-modified pdtz2- ligands. In addition, the free bpp ligand usually emits intense luminescence at ca. 523nm , obviously different from the emission peak of compound 2 (489nm). Further, the free 2,2'-bipy ligand generally displays a weak luminescence at ca. 530nm , also far from the emission peak of compound 3 (486nm). The blue shifts of emission bands occurring in 2 and 3 are probably due to the cooperative effects of intraligand emission and ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) .
